topic.title: Connectivity Architecture
topic.shortdesc: Couchbase Server handles client to cluster, node to node, and cluster to cluster communications.

section.title: Client to Cluster
section.p: Client applications communicate with Couchbase Server through a set of server-defined access-points, each of which provides ports for both clear and encrypted communication.
The five principal access-points are as follows:

row.entry: Direct connection to a single node in the cluster, to perform administrative operations, monitoring, and alerting.
Query with View (View and Spatial View API)
Load-balanced connection across cluster-nodes running the Data Service for View queries.
Load-balanced connection across cluster-nodes running the Query Service for N1QL queries.
Stateful connections from a client to cluster-nodes running the Data Service for CRUD operations.
Load-balanced connections across cluster-nodes running the Search Service for Full Text Search queries.

section.p: Note that the above table lists only a subset of the network ports. For a complete list, see .

body.section:
Node to Node
Cluster-nodes intercommunicate in order to replicate data, maintain indexes, check health of nodes, communicate changes to the cluster-configuration, and more. See Cluster Manager, for detailed information.

section.title: Cluster to Cluster
section.p: Couchbase Server clusters communicate with one other by means of Cross Datacenter Replication (XDCR). See Availability, for detailed information.

section.title: Cluster to External Connector
section.p: Couchbase Server also communicates with third party products, using connectors. Support is provided for Elasticsearch, Hadoop, Kafka, Spark, and Talend. Drivers are provided for ODBC and JDBC. See , for detailed information.

section.title: Connectivity Phases
section.p: Client connectivity is established in three phases: authentication and authorization, discovery, and service connection.

ol.li: Authentication and Authorization: The client authenticates with username and password. If these are associated with a Couchbase-Server defined role, itself associated with appropriate privileges on the resources access to which is being attempted, the client is authorized. Otherwise, access is refused. See Authorization for details.

Discovery: A cluster map is returned to the client. This indicates the current cluster-topology; including the list of nodes, the data-distribution across the nodes, and the service-distribution accross the nodes.

Service Connection: Once in possession of the cluster map, the client determines the connections needed to establish and perform service-level operations. Additional authorizations may be required, depending on the operations attempting. Note that in the event of topology-changes, a service connection may receive an exception; in which case discovery can be re-run, and operations retried with new connections.
